frontmatter.title: Profiling Jupyter Notebook Code with Py-Spy
frontmatter.description: When you sync your Jupyter notebooks with Jupytext, you get all the benefits of having a flat Python script, including the ability to get really flame graphs from Py-Spy.

frontmatter.title: Comparing Collaborative Filtering Methods
frontmatter.description: I wanted to dive into the fundamentals of collaborative filtering and recommender systems, so I implemented a few common methods and compared them.

frontmatter.title: Deploying a Cookiecutter Django Site on AWS
frontmatter.description: The Django Cookiecutter template is an amazing tool to start up a Django project with all the bells and whistles ready to go. Getting your production site up and running can still be a bit of a hassle though, so to save myself, and hopefully a few others, from this hassle in the future, I'm recording all the steps that worked for me here.

frontmatter.title: Running Jupyter Lab Remotely
frontmatter.description: I'm a huge fan of Jupyter Notebooks, and I was very excited when I found out about Jupyter Lab, which provides a much more comprehensive user experience around Jupyter Notebooks. Here I share how to run Jupyter Lab efficiently on a remote machine. I have a research cluster where I do most of my analyses for my PhD work, and running Jupyter Lab directly on the cluster means I don't have to copy files between the cluster and my desktop.

frontmatter.title: Taking Advantage of Sparsity in the ALS-WR Algorithm
frontmatter.description: The ALS-WR algorithm works well for recommender systems involving a sparse matrix of users by items to review, which happens when most people only review a small subset of many possible items (businesses, movies, etc.). By tweaking the code from a great tutorial to take advantage of this sparsity, I was able to dramatically reduce the computation time.

frontmatter.title: Analyzing Larger-than-Memory Data on your Laptop
frontmatter.description: If you want to run some analysis on a dataset that's just a little too big to load into memory on your laptop, but you don't want to leave the comfort of using Pandas dataframes in a Jupyter notebook, then Dask may be just your thing. Dask is an amazing Python library that lets you do all your Pandas-style dataframe manipulations with just a few simple tweaks so you don't have to worry about Jupyter freezing up.

frontmatter.title: Dealing with Grid Data in Python
frontmatter.description: In my PhD research, I do a lot of analysis of 2D and 3D grid data output by simulations I run. In my analyses, it's very helpful to restructure these data into a more useable format. A few key lines of python code do the trick.

frontmatter.title: Interactive D3 Map of Baby Name Popularity
frontmatter.description: I built a D3 map showing baby name popularity by state with an interactive time slider you can use to see how the popularity changes over time. Come check it out!

frontmatter.title: Parameter Sweep Bash Script
frontmatter.description: In my polymer field theory research, often my studies involve running a bunch of simulations where I pick one or more input parameters and change them over a range of values, then compare the results of each separate simulation to see how that/those variable(s) affect the system Iâ€™m simulating. It can be very tedious to manually create input files for each job, so I wrote a bash script to help me out.
